response.answer_text: The industry momentum is towards total replacement of humans for software development. Hardware was the model. No one found anything other than high level research jobs since the late 70s. Commercial software for business is somewhat of an exception. The software market has been turned into a used car environment. The product doesn’t have to pass any standards. It just has to sell. That is the standard. Software is now like dog food. The one who has to eat it is not the one who buys it. So, pretty marketing and promises gets high paid executives to dump the software in place for a new, improved version. They can blame the previous managers for a bad choice. Next comes the realization that all users will need training. This will not necessarily solve anything substantial and will be costly. The goal is to get $300/hr consultants in the store to fix and modify the software. These people may not even know anything but the phone number of the person to supply an answer. It’s astounding. So sleazy.
